snippet: The disagreement between American and Israeli leaders over a proposed deal to freeze Iran’s nuclear program is about more than negotiating tactics — it reflects a clash of fundamental goals.
abstract: Divergent views have deeply politicized question of whether accord to freeze Iran's nuclear program that United States and its European allies are considering should be termed good deal or bad one; fundamental disagreement has left in tatters whatever efforts Pres Obama and Israel's Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu have made over past five years to say they are on same page.

byline.original: By DAVID E. SANGER and JODI RUDOREN
byline.contributor: David E. Sanger reported from Washington, and Jodi Rudoren from Jerusalem. Steven Erlanger contributed from New York, Isabel Kershner from Jerusalem, and Mark Landler from Washington.

lead_paragraph: The disagreement between American and Israeli leaders over a proposed deal to freeze Iran’s nuclear program is about more than negotiating tactics — it reflects a clash of fundamental goals.

headline.main: Split on Accord on Iran Strains U.S.-Israel Ties
headline.print_headline: Split on Accord on Iran Strains U.S.-Israel Ties
